snippet.textDisplay: I grew up with evangelion and gundam. Watching gridman and a few others just seemed cheesy to me. It's all about phases. It's like this last decade has been strongly about superhero films, things change and mecha has just got cheesy and overplayed through a lot of different things. I think the fact we could see mecha being made in the not so long future makes it less fantasy like which takes away from the fantasy of anime.

snippet.textDisplay:
Gigguk if you read this, just go on and enjoy your christmas and have a happy new year. If you don't make a best of 2019 it's fine by me and probably by a lot of people who enjoy your content.


And even if you make one since it's your passion project I understand why it would be delayed since like many creators out there including myself, you want it to be perfect. And honestly I don't give a shit in how long it'll take - just make it when you're ready and when you feel it is ready. :3


Enjoy and a happy 2020 to you and your fam!

snippet.textDisplay:
@gigguk


I would love to see a well-written story with an intro similar to the second pacific rim project. Specifically calling out Mecha as the current day humans answer to "What do we do when confronted with the absolute?" (We invent.) https://youtu.be/mwQLIkHHD6g?t=3 hard cut at about 0:40 seconds.

We strive, sacrifice, and build something that offers an individual the power of an army battalion concentrated and refined behind a single HOTAS control scheme to fight the battles that no one else can. We follow those characters because we care about the consequences of their actions, and understand the risks and power behind the choices they make. (Often characters are burdened with the power to literally burn down the world around them {pick any buster weapon that can destroy a side or colony vessel}; rarely do I see that explored with any depth.)

If we can find a studio that can blend in some drama and romance so much the better as long as we can avoid the pitfalls of an act two honeymoon (looking at you Dahlin) and an implosion of the narrative.

Cheers mates,
snippet.textOriginal:
@gigguk


I would love to see a well-written story with an intro similar to the second pacific rim project. Specifically calling out Mecha as the current day humans answer to "What do we do when confronted with the absolute?" (We invent.) https://youtu.be/mwQLIkHHD6g?t=3 hard cut at about 0:40 seconds. 

We strive, sacrifice, and build something that offers an individual the power of an army battalion concentrated and refined behind a single HOTAS control scheme to fight the battles that no one else can. We follow those characters because we care about the consequences of their actions, and understand the risks and power behind the choices they make. (Often characters are burdened with the power to literally burn down the world around them {pick any buster weapon that can destroy a side or colony vessel}; rarely do I see that explored with any depth.)

If we can find a studio that can blend in some drama and romance so much the better as long as we can avoid the pitfalls of an act two honeymoon (looking at you Dahlin) and an implosion of the narrative. 

Cheers mates,

snippet.textDisplay: hmm there is alot of anime i have not seen, what anime or mecha anime in the past would you recommend ? also i havnt seen almost any gundam other than some of gundam wing, tho the reason for that, is to me gundam is about the horrors of war and lose and that useing violence to solve problems, that were created by violence will not work. much like how if you read the robotech book series, alot of it was amazing and really great, but the last few books, at the end of the series, i feel that the author has decided to burn the words war is bad, on the side of a spear and then stab you with a dozen times. to me that was the point of gundam wing, war is bad so i didnt watch to the end. i felt, i had gotten the point, more than a few times really.

I was just happy to see Broken/Brake Blade.
Hope the new gundam series will help to attract new fans. Even guys who are gunpla/model kits sellers and long time fans want some new stuff. Whether it is animated or cgi. The new youtube exclusive series Obsolete was great.
Hope for more. Being 27 and remembering wing as one of the first things i saw when i came to Europe as a kid, was awesome. Hope for a little more mecha but i hope more, for better mecha.

snippet.textDisplay:
Perhaps mecha was always a niche interest. Anime encompasses a wide genre and normies only really like normie stuff, attack on titan and MHA, so if those people keep coming in the fandom, Mecha is further sidelined.


Also Mecha just doesn't work on an economic scale, its toys are more difficult to manufacture than figurines and thus more expensive and this sell less. People like visuals and giant mechs lost that in comparison to idealized moe stuff.


You cannot get a warm fuzzy feeling from just a mech, but you can from a cute moe girl. Even if you add the proper set up, you lose when compared to a cute girl getting that set up. The best thing you can do is stuff like Symphogear, cute mech girls, great soundtrack, (plot isn't perfect but meh) and you got your mech and cute girl.


Mecha is competing with normies for just general fans of anime. In terms of hardcore, they are beaten hard by cute girls. Unfortunately mecha (as in giant robots) is stuck between a rock and hard place.


The times do not favor Mecha if your goal is to attract new fans. However, mecha has always stood the test of time because it is niche. If it is niche, it will survive, though it may not thrive.
snippet.textOriginal:

Also Mecha just doesn't work on an economic scale, its toys are more difficult to manufacture than figurines and thus more expensive and this sell less. People like visuals and giant mechs lost that in comparison to idealized moe stuff.


You cannot get a warm fuzzy feeling from just a mech, but you can from a cute moe girl. Even if you add the proper set up, you lose when compared to a cute girl getting that set up. The best thing you can do is stuff like Symphogear, cute mech girls, great soundtrack, (plot isn't perfect but meh) and you got your mech and cute girl.


Mecha is competing with normies for just general fans of anime. In terms of hardcore, they are beaten hard by cute girls. Unfortunately mecha (as in giant robots) is stuck between a rock and hard place.


The times do not favor Mecha if your goal is to attract new fans. However, mecha has always stood the test of time because it is niche. If it is niche, it will survive, though it may not thrive.

snippet.textDisplay:
Honustly, i been a Mecha fan ever since i got introduced to Tekkaman Blade on a vacation..
I been up from Gundam to Votoms to Patlabor. To me Mecha are things you Pilot, unlike (super) Robot series.

What i see in your video is exactly how i feel. Most of the current Mecha series are either to stupid for me to watch. Or while visually stunning, i only watch because it IS mecha..
One series i however have noticed you missed, and something i have followed since the manga started. 'Knight & Magic'. This is something that Gets you into the mecha without Introducing the mecha as a major plot.
True Ald.noah is the same but the plot just gets to absurd. Same with most of the other series. Code Geast, Gurren Lagann, etc.

If today i have a need to recommend a modern Mecha for people who ask me. I usually suggest 'Kuromukuro', 'ID-0', 'Knight & Magic' or 'The Price of Smiles'.
As you say, the more hardcore series are to hard to get into without being atleast interested in Mecha itself.
I mean i recently had a hard time to suggest 'Argevollen' to a friend who has been a Fan of NGE and ZOE. And had to settle for watch FLAG together.

One series i however have noticed you missed, and something i have followed since the manga started. 'Knight & Magic'. This is something that Gets you into the mecha without Introducing the mecha as a major plot. 
True Ald.noah is the same but the plot just gets to absurd. Same with most of the other series. Code Geast, Gurren Lagann, etc.

If today i have a need to recommend a *modern* Mecha for people who ask me. I usually suggest 'Kuromukuro', 'ID-0', 'Knight & Magic' or 'The Price of Smiles'.

snippet.textDisplay: Gundam 00 reignited my love for Gundam that had long since been gone from my childhood where I was obsessed with Gundam wing. snippet.textOriginal: Gundam 00 reignited my love for Gundam that had long since been gone from my childhood where I was obsessed with Gundam wing. snippet.textDisplay:
I like mecha because they're giant machines that are mechanically interesting. If you stick too many tiny details on you lose my interest.


Watching these videos I have to say that CG did ruin the genre. With hand art you have to balance detail vs visual efficiency, and you get interesting designs that are easy to follow in their action. With CG you have infinite detail possible in your models and it's hard to tell what's going on.


The same sort of thing happens in the Michael Bay Transformers movies - the models have too much tiny detail and it spoils the aesthetic.
snippet.textOriginal:
I like mecha because they're giant *machines* that are mechanically interesting. If you stick too many tiny details on you lose my interest.


Watching these videos I have to say that CG *did* ruin the genre. With hand art you have to balance detail vs visual efficiency, and you get interesting designs that are easy to follow in their action. With CG you have infinite detail possible in your models and it's hard to tell what's going on. 


The same sort of thing happens in the Michael Bay Transformers movies - the models have too much tiny detail and it spoils the aesthetic.
